description.name: sense,lifeworlds,to describe,needs & aspirations
description.desc:
Sense life worlds to describe needs & aspirations
Using senses as a tool for understanding cities involves immersing ourselves in their sensory experiences. By engaging with the sights, sounds, and even the tactile sensations of urban environments, we can discern their unique rhythms, cultures, and dynamics.

This sensory-driven approach deepens our connection to cities, unveiling layers of meaning that go beyond conventional analyses.
Lifeworld refers to the subjective and experiential reality of individuals within their immediate living environment. In the context of livable spaces, lifeworld encompasses the personal perceptions, emotions, and interactions that individuals have with their surroundings. It includes how people interpret and make sense of their environment, the routines and rituals they engage in, and the emotional connections they develop with the spaces they inhabit. Understanding lifeworld is crucial for creating truly livable spaces that cater to the holistic needs and well-being of the people who inhabit them.
To describe n refers to the process of articulating and detailing the various sensory, experiential, and perceptual aspects of the environment. This involves using language to convey the visual, auditory, tactile, and even emotional qualities of a place, capturing its unique character, ambiance, and the feelings it evokes. describing livable spaces enables individuals to share their perspectives, insights, and personal connections, contributing to a richer and more comprehensive understanding of the environment's impact on human experience. needs & aspirations is important because it helps us to understand the needs and aspirations of people who inhabit the spaces we design. This allows us to create environments that not only fulfill basic needs but also foster a sense of fulfillment, belonging, and personal development.

description.name: sugpat-youth-talks:-scale-models-for-participatory-imagining.jpg
description.desc:
SUGPAT Youth Talks: Scale Models for Participatory Imagining
Armed with nothing but a handful of art materials, their creative spirits, and the hope for a safer Zamboanga, almost a hundred youth came together to re-imagine safe spaces in Asia’s Latin City last August 17 at Palacio del Sur, Zamboanga City. In line with the National Youth Commission’s celebration of International Youth Day with the theme “Safe Spaces for the Youth,” miniature models of the ideal safe community were built by the youth as an output during “SUGPAT Youth Talks #2: Creating Safe Spaces for the Youth.” This is the second iteration of the SUGPAT Youth Talks, a series of fora uniquely designed to discuss timely issues and programs, identify areas of convergence, and leverage resources for better outcomes for Filipino children and adolescents.

description.name: chulalongkorn-university-centenary-park,-bangkok.jpg
description.desc:
Chulalongkorn University Centenary Park, Bangkok
Opened in 2017, Chulalongkorn Centenary Park is the first critical piece of green infrastructure in Bangkok to mitigate detrimental ecological issues and disaster risk reduction. Unlike other public parks around the city, this one is the first in Thailand to demonstrate how a park can help reduce urban flood risks and help city confronts climate change, all while offering city dwellers a place to reconnect with nature. Designed with various ecological design components, the park reminds the city of ways to live with water, rather than fear it.

description.name: 15-minute-city.jpg
description.desc:
15-Minute City
The "15-Minute City" is an urban planning concept that envisions cities designed to ensure that residents can access most of their daily needs and activities within a 15-minute walk or bike ride from their homes. This concept promotes compact, mixed-use neighborhoods with easy access to services, jobs, green spaces, and public transportation. The goal is to reduce dependence on cars, decrease traffic congestion, lower pollution, and improve overall urban livability by creating more self-sufficient and sustainable urban environments.

description.name: lego-blocks-in-participatory-planning.jpg
description.desc:
LEGO blocks in participatory planning
The use of LEGO bricks in participatory urban planning, as demonstrated by Olafur Eliasson's LEGO town planning projects in Denmark and Albania, highlights the versatility and creativity these iconic building blocks bring to the field. This approach effectively engages communities in the collaborative design of urban spaces. By involving residents in the co-creation of their city's future, LEGO becomes a valuable tool for fostering a sense of ownership and pride in shaping more sustainable and vibrant urban environments.

description.name: road-pricing.jpg
description.desc:
Road pricing
Road pricing has been shown to be an effective way to reduce congestion through making it more expensive to use cars. In road pricing, drivers are charged toll fees when they use specific roads. This aims to discourage driving unless absolutely necessary, and is usually used to regulate cars going into city centres or using high-end roads like expressways. One notable example is Singapore’s Electronic Road Pricing (ERP) system, which uses electronic gates to automatically charge drivers passing through, without needing drivers to slow down or queue to pay toll fees in cash. While road pricing has been shown to work in Singapore and London, it is not always an appropriate solution. There have to be alternative ways for people to get to their destinations; for example, Singapore has invested into public transportation so that people do not need to drive to move from their homes to their jobs in the city centre. This might not be a good solution for cities that do not have the infrastructure to give people alternatives. It is also a hard policy to sell to voters, especially in countries that have a deep car culture. If a government is sure that they want to do road pricing, they must convince citizens that this is beneficial for them while also making the effort to mitigate negative outcomes such as lower-income workers being unable to access jobs. This is why it is important to adapt all solutions, including road pricing, to the local context.

description.name: community-gardens.jpg
description.desc:
Community gardens
Community gardens are a proven strategy for fostering sustainable urban living by transforming unused spaces into vibrant hubs of local food production and community engagement. In community gardens, residents collectively cultivate fruits, vegetables, and herbs, often on city-owned or communal land. These green pockets not only provide fresh, locally grown produce but also serve as spaces for social interaction and skill-sharing among community members. One exemplary case is the "P-Patch" program in Seattle, Washington, which has successfully established over 50 community gardens throughout the city. These gardens have become essential components of neighborhood life, promoting urban sustainability while also offering a sense of belonging and community pride. However, the viability of community gardens can vary based on local factors. It's essential to ensure that adequate land is available for garden plots and that there's community interest and commitment to maintaining the gardens. Additionally, successful community garden initiatives often require ongoing support and education to help residents maximize their gardening potential. This solution may not be universally suitable, especially in densely populated urban areas with limited available land. In such cases, vertical or rooftop gardening may be explored as alternatives. Moreover, cultural and demographic factors should be considered, as community gardening may not align with the preferences or traditions of all residents. To effectively implement community gardens, local governments and community organizations should tailor their approaches to suit the specific needs and interests of the area. Building partnerships with local schools, businesses, and non-profits can help provide resources, education, and a sense of shared responsibility, ensuring that community gardens thrive and contribute positively to the local urban environment

description.name: regenerative-design.jpg
description.desc:
Regenerative Design
Regenerative design, as exemplified in the book "Flourish" by Sarah Ichioka and Michael Pawlyn, is a holistic and sustainable approach to design and architecture that seeks to create regenerative and thriving ecosystems. It goes beyond traditional sustainability by aiming to restore and enhance natural systems while meeting human needs. This approach emphalevels biomimicry, drawing inspiration from nature's designs and processes to develop innovative and environmentally-friendly solutions. Regenerative design not only minimizes negative impacts but actively contributes to the regeneration of ecosystems, fostering a harmonious relationship between human-made structures and the natural world.

description.name: participatory-budgeting---a-seoul-case-study.jpg
description.desc:
Participatory Budgeting - a Seoul Case Study
Participatory budgeting in Seoul is a groundbreaking approach that empowers citizens to directly influence the allocation of public funds and resources in their city. Through this inclusive process, residents have the opportunity to propose, discuss, and prioritize various community projects and initiatives. Seoul's commitment to participatory budgeting reflects a strong desire for transparency, accountability, and citizen engagement in municipal decision-making. By involving residents in shaping the city's budget priorities, Seoul not only enhances civic participation but also fosters a sense of ownership and responsibility among its citizens, ultimately contributing to more responsive and community-driven urban development.

description.name: bike-sharing.jpg
description.desc:
Bike-sharing
Bike-sharing programs are popular urban mobility solutions, providing sustainable transportation options while reducing traffic congestion and emissions. These programs offer short-term bicycle rentals through strategically placed docking stations, making them convenient for short trips and commutes. A notable case study is the Citi Bike program in New York City, one of the largest and most successful bike-sharing systems in the United States. Launched in 2013, Citi Bike has provided millions of residents and tourists with a flexible, eco-friendly mode of transportation. With thousands of bikes and hundreds of docking stations, it has become an integral part of New York City's transportation landscape, reducing reliance on cars and taxis. However, successful bike-sharing relies on factors like dedicated bike lanes, public awareness, and local infrastructure. It may not be suitable for all cities, depending on factors like topography and cultural preferences. To implement bike-sharing effectively, cities should assess local conditions, infrastructure, and community interest to tailor the program to their unique needs and maximize its benefits.

description.name: mass-transit.jpg
description.desc:
Mass transit
Mass transit systems are transformative urban solutions that provide efficient, affordable, and sustainable transportation options for densely populated cities, even in challenging circumstances. One remarkable example comes from Bogotá, Colombia, which faced daunting traffic congestion and limited resources. Bogotá successfully implemented its Bus Rapid Transit (BRT) system, known as TransMilenio, to address these challenges. TransMilenio features dedicated bus lanes, stations with rapid boarding, and integrated fare collection. This system has significantly reduced congestion, improved air quality, and provided affordable transportation for millions of residents. Despite facing economic constraints common in developing countries, Bogotá's TransMilenio demonstrates that mass transit solutions can be both effective and resource-efficient. While adapting such systems to other urban areas, local factors such as population density, existing infrastructure, and public transportation habits should be considered. Successful implementation also requires strong leadership, community engagement, and ongoing maintenance to ensure that mass transit continues to benefit urban populations.

description.name: gamified-traffic-simulation.jpg
description.desc:
Gamified traffic simulation
Norra Djurgårdstaden is an area in central Stockholm that’s currently undergoing substantial urban redevelopment. The Swedish Building Service, Svensk Byggtjänst, has partnered with city officials and, with a focus on long-term sustainability, the on-going initiative plans to add 12,000 new homes and 35,000 workspaces to the region in a bid to offset its ever-increasing population. How does this relate to the world of videogames? City-building simulator Cities: Skylinesis at the forefront of the project. By simulating real-life environments and scenarios in-game, Paradox and Colossal Order’s city-builder is being used by real-world city planners to explore ways to support the needs of the new district’s residents. “Norra Djurgårdstaden is seeking new ways of engaging people that are normally not involved in the discussions of the future of our city, and how to plan for its desired direction,” says project director Staffan Lorentz. “Games can be an entry port for a new group having a real say and having new ways of looking at things.”

description.name: heritage-preservation.jpg
description.desc:
Heritage preservation
Heritage preservation is a crucial aspect of urban planning, dedicated to safeguarding and revitalizing culturally significant sites, buildings, and traditions that reflect a nation's history and identity. This practice plays a vital role in preserving a country's cultural heritage for future generations. India's efforts to preserve its rich cultural heritage offer a noteworthy example. The country has successfully conserved historic temples, palaces, and ancient cities like Jaipur through meticulous restoration and adaptive reuse. These efforts not only protect valuable heritage but also boost tourism and economic development. However, heritage preservation in the Global South often encounters unique challenges, including limited resources and rapid urbanization pressures. Adaptive strategies, such as repurposing heritage sites for community activities or small-scale tourism ventures, can be sustainable solutions. Implementing heritage preservation in Global South countries necessitates tailored approaches that consider local conditions, engage with communities, and find innovative ways to balance preservation with urban growth. Clear guidelines, partnerships with heritage organizations, and grassroots involvement are essential for preserving the cultural identity and heritage of these nations.

description.name: volunteered-geographic-information:-a-haiti-case-study.jpg
description.desc:
Volunteered Geographic Information: a Haiti Case Study
In 2010, a disastrous earthquake hit Port-au-Prince in Haiti. At the time, humanitarian relief efforts were hampered by a lack of quality geospatial data on the city, even in commercial mapping platforms. Volunteers stepped up to map the city on OpenStreetMap, and an understanding of the city's road network, major landmarks, and crisis stress points emerged that enabled humanitarian teams to deliver significantly improved disaster relief. This is an example of how volunteered geographic information (VGI) can help in solving complex urban problems: by speeding up data acquisition while also bringing communities together and inspiring collective action and resilience.

description.name: transit-oriented-development.jpg
description.desc:
Transit-Oriented Development
Transit-Oriented Development (TOD) is an urban planning concept that aims to create sustainable and connected communities by integrating various modes of transportation with retail and community centers. This approach focuses on reducing car dependency, promoting public transit use, and enhancing the overall urban living experience. An illustrative case of TOD can be found in Jakarta, Indonesia. In response to the city's rapid urbanization and traffic congestion, Jakarta has embarked on ambitious TOD initiatives. By strategically placing commercial and residential developments around transit hubs like the Jakarta MRT and TransJakarta Bus Rapid Transit (BRT) system, the city has not only improved transportation access but also fostered vibrant, mixed-use neighborhoods. TOD projects like these in Jakarta have the potential to reduce traffic congestion, lower carbon emissions, and improve the quality of life for residents. They encourage people to rely less on private vehicles, promoting walking, cycling, and the use of public transportation for daily commuting and leisure activities. Successful TOD implementation depends on adapting the concept to local conditions and needs. Collaboration between government authorities, developers, and community stakeholders is essential to ensure that TOD initiatives align with the specific goals and characteristics of each urban area. By doing so, TOD can contribute to the creation of more sustainable, livable, and connected cities worldwide.

description.name: turku-3d-model-survey.jpg
description.desc:
Turku 3D model survey
The University of Turku and the City of Turku in Finland collaborated on a pilot project that tested 3D participatory planning. Their research team created an engagement survey based on 3D maps. The public was asked to comment on the city planning project — the redevelopment plan of the Aninkainen district in Turku, which is one of the largest urban areas in Finland.

description.name: mobile-phone-data.jpg
description.desc:
Mobile Phone Data
The integration of mobile phone geolocation, mobility, and survey data has emerged as a game-changer in urban planning, offering invaluable insights into urban dynamics and transforming the way cities are designed and managed. By analyzing geolocation data from mobile phones, urban planners gain real-time information about traffic patterns, population movements, and transportation infrastructure usage. This data can inform decisions related to traffic management, public transportation planning, and the optimization of urban infrastructure. For example, in Singapore, the government utilizes mobile phone data to monitor and improve public transportation services, reducing congestion and enhancing mobility. Additionally, survey data collected through mobile apps and platforms enable residents to contribute their preferences and feedback on urban development projects, fostering a more participatory and citizen-centric approach to urban planning. This integration of data sources empowers cities to make informed decisions, enhance livability, and create more sustainable and responsive urban environments.
